facts.text: These are six consolidated appeals arising out of a common judgment and six separate orders of the High Court of Judicature at Patna with certificates under section 66A(2) of the Indian Income-tax Act.
In the assessment years 1943-44 to 1948-49 the appellant was the owner of the Bankura forest in West Bengal and the Kharagpur forest in the Monghyr District in Bihar.

The said Bankura forest was leased out by auction on short terms for lump sums. According to the terms of the lease the lessee was entitled to cut down and remove all sal trees but those which were more than three feet in girth and three feet from the ground and all other jungle trees other than fruit bearing trees and valuable timber trees. The lessee was further entitled to cut stumps not higher than five feet over ground.

Lessee to refrain from entering the forests during rains when new shoots come out and guard the forests from trespassing by men and cattle. On the conclusion of the stipulated period the lessee loses all rights, even the right to enter the land.
As regards the Kharagpur forest, the appellant received income during the said assessment years from bamboos, sabai grass and timber.
All these (bamboos, sabai grass, timber) are grown wild and spontaneously. In 1944 a working plan was formulated for felling mature bamboo trees in rotation from sub-divided compartments.
It cannot be said that any human agency was responsible for either plantation or the growth of the bamboos. The position with regard to sabai grass is more or less the same.

With regard to timber trees, there was a scheme by which the sal and ebony trees which grow in the forests were conserved by allowing each tree a circle of 15 feet by clearing the jungle of other trees which fall within this area, thus leaving sufficient space for the growth.
Wells were sunk but they were not for the purpose of watering the trees but were for supplying drinking water for the cartmen and bullocks which go into the forests to bring out the timber.

It is alleged that coppice work was also undertaken near about 1883 but the only evidence is a government annual administration report dated 5th October, 1882, of forest administration in Bihar suggesting that private owners should take up growth of coppice forests for being worked in short rotation for fuel supply.

There is also letter No. 170 dated 14th April, 1883, of the Commissioner, Bhagalpur Division, addressed to the Manager, Darbhanga Raj, regarding preservation of sal saplings in the forests of neighbouring zamindars Gidhour and Banaily Raj but only in the 1944 correspondence there is evidence to show that coppice compartments of sal trees on the higher elevation of rocky hills were proposed to be worked in 7 years.

From this it is clear that there was no human agency with reference to the production of the plant from the soil although there was some element of human activity with reference to assisting the growth of some of the trees.

Specific receipts: Rs. 7,436 and Rs. 11,468 (1349 Fasli), Rs. 23,581 and Rs. 17,027 (1350 Fasli), Rs. 20,582 and Rs. 59,514 (1351 Fasli), Rs. 14,750 and Rs. 98,969 (1352 Fasli), Rs. 13,836 and Rs. 1,17,173 (1353 Fasli), Rs. 22,211 and Rs. 73,449 (1354 Fasli) from Bankura and Kharagpur forests respectively.

Assessment orders made under section 23 of the Indian Income-tax Act on 15th March, 1944, 9th March, 1945, 27th March, 1946, 12th March, 1947, 13th March, 1948, and 24th February, 1946, rejecting contentions that receipts were capital receipts or agricultural income.
Appeals to Appellate Assistant Commissioner or Additional Appellate Assistant Commissioner dismissed, confirming assessments.
Further appeals to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, rejected and assessments confirmed.
Tribunal refused reference under section 66(1), but High Court directed reference under section 66(2).
High Court answered questions in the negative against appellant.

legal_issues.text: Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the receipts of Bankura forest lease are capital receipts or, in the alternative, constitute agricultural income?
Whether in the facts and circumstances of the case, the receipts from Kharagpur forest are agricultural income?

petitioner_arguments.text: The two sums received from Bankura and Kharagpur forests were not taxable as they were (i) capital receipts and/or (ii) agricultural income.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: section 2(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: Receipts are taxable income, not capital receipts or agricultural income.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Income-tax Act assessments under section 23

court_reasoning.text: High Court decided against appellant on ground that there was no material to hold any expenditure of human skill and labour upon the land so as to constitute agricultural income within section 2(1). Conservation measures like allowing 15 feet circle and employment of conservancy staff not sufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No material on which to hold expenditure of human skill and labour upon the land.

court_reasoning.text: Principles from Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy: For forest trees of spontaneous growth, unaided by human skill/labour, no basic operations in agriculture performed on soil, no cultivation. Operations are subsequent forestry operations for conservation/growth, not basic operations essential to agriculture.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Operations had nothing in common with basic agricultural operations and did not convert spontaneous forest produce into agricultural produce.

court_reasoning.text: High Court was right; questions rightly answered against appellant.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appeals must be dismissed with costs.

holdings.text: Receipts from Bankura and Kharagpur forests are not capital receipts nor agricultural income; taxable as income.
Receipts from Kharagpur forest are not agricultural income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Mustafa Ali Khan v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Dictum on expenditure of human skill and labour upon land for agricultural income.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Raja Benoy Kumar Sahas Roy
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles governing forestry operations on spontaneous growth trees; distinction between basic and subsequent operations.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificates for appeal; assessment orders; reference to High Court; definition of agricultural income.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the six consolidated appeals with costs, upholding the High Court's decision that the receipts from Bankura and Kharagpur forests are neither capital receipts nor agricultural income, but taxable income.

key_quotes.text: in regard to the forest trees of spontaneous growth, which grow on the soil unaided by any human skill and labour and where no basic operations in agriculture are performed upon the soil itself by the assessee, there is no cultivation of the soil at all.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when forest produce is not agricultural income.

key_quotes.text: These subsequent operations though they may have the effect of nursing and fostering the growth of such forest trees have nothing in common with the basic operations which are the efficient cause of raising these products from the soil.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes basic agricultural operations from forestry conservation.
